title: Using DiaCollo for Historical Research

author: Maret Nieländer, Georg Eckert Institute for International Textbook Research
Bryan Jurish, Berlin-Brandenburg Academy of Sciences and Humanities

segmentation: Hi, my name is Brian and I am a computational linguist and this is Margaret and she is a historian and we'll be talking today as we said about some software called Yacullo and.

Thank you.

So this is a very simple model of the iterative software development cycle.

Briefly, what what came out of the planning phase we have on the one hand, diachronic text corpora write text collections which extend overtime, and what?
We as users would like is to get.
Time sensitive or date sensitive phenomena out of them, so things like semantic shift, discourse trends, neologisms, etc.
That's problematic for conventional NLP tools.
In particular, the way we wanted to go around about it was with collocation profiling.
The idea here is the software prompts the user for a target.
A call account of interest, so the user comes has to know what he or she is interested in.
Then the software looks up everything that Co occurs with that whatever Co occurs with means.
And then ranks all those candidates by some more or less intelligent statistical score.
The idea here is not to just see function words like the and on in the top.
List.
If we want to do that for a diachronic corpus, if we want to do that diachronically.
The problem is that conventional tools assume 1 corpus one thing.
It trades corpus as a homogeneous whole and ignores the influence of the current state and the solution that we.
Implemented Indiaca was to actually pack the date into what it means to be a term, so only terms that occur at the same date can really Co occur, and then the rest of the math just works out.
It's implemented in the best of all possible languages, Perl.
And it's it's language agnostic, which is nice from from a software perspective, but irritating from a user perspective, I think because it means that the user.
Has to tokenize an annotate their corpora themselves, which.
Can be difficult and more frustrating for the users.
As a statistical method, it's it's sensitive to garbage in, garbage out phenomena.
So if you feed it a messy OCR corpus, you're less likely to be very satisfied with the results that come out.
Then if you feed it a well curated clean corpus.

Now everything should be clear.

8000 pages, so that's too much even for the best historian for a quick close reading, but it's enough and great corpus to use the yacullo, so at first I'm.
